name: Lily AOSE
comment info:
This graph shows the results of the 2024 state legislature elections, where most states have a bicameral legislature with a Senate (upper chamber) and a House of Representatives (lower chamber). What stands out is that Alaska is unique in having a complete split in both chambers, with no dominant political philosophy. Michigan is the only state that flipped party control in 2024, while most other states have one party holding the majority in both chambers, except for Pennsylvania and Minnesota, where control is divided. I wonder how these shifts will affect things long-term—will divided legislatures like Pennsylvania and Minnesota find common ground, or will it lead to gridlock? What would a "Trifecta" mean for a state like mine, where one party controls everything? This relates to my community because I live in a blue state, and if the legislature focuses on progressive policies, it could mean more funding for healthcare, education, and infrastructure. However, there's also the risk that other needs—especially those that don't align with the dominant political views—could get overlooked.
Headline: 2024 State Legislature Elections: A Look at Legislative Shifts Nationwide

name: Johan P3
comment info:
Most state legislatures are controlled by Republicans, as indicated by the widespread presence of red across states. Blue states are mainly concentrated in the Northeast, West Coast, and a few other areas like Colorado and Minnesota. Only a few states have split legislatures, meaning different parties control the upper and lower chambers. Some states have flipped legislative control, as marked by the small red and blue blocks indicating a change in party dominance. Many states have a single-party trifecta (governor and both chambers controlled by one party), reinforcing strong partisan governance.

name: Michael Blazin
comment info:
Nebraska has the right idea.  The senate in each legislature follows the same apportionment rules as the state representatives.  There are fewer state senators so their districts are bigger.  It is still one person one vote. Consequently, you would expect the House and Senate sides to usually be in agreement. Anytime you see a split, the margin of control in one of the houses is likely very slim. Being bicameral does not do much for the state and wastes a lot of money.

The status of the governor would be the most important new info. Control of both houses, but a different party as governor means that you don’t have much control.  If a different governor is rare, then you could say democracy is working since you cannot gerrymander the governor’s seat.  

For other reasons, states are sifting out other party’s followers leaving primary battles as the overwhelming elections where voters make their choices.

New voters will get increasingly fewer as the population changes, increasing the dominance of middle aged and older voters.  That means things are not going to change for a long time
